properties.NAME: VitraHaus Cafe
properties.DESCRIPTION: At the café, you can enjoy a regularly updated menu of fresh regional specialities. When the weather is nice, you can relax on the terrace or in the meadow at the foot of the Tüllinger Hill. The café and the adjacent terrace can be booked for private events after 6pm.

properties.NAME: Lounge Chair Atelier
properties.DESCRIPTION: Witness first-hand the craftsmanship that goes into the making of a Vitra classic. At the Lounge Chair Atelier, you can select your preferred design of the Eames Lounge Chair & Ottoman –– its wooden shells, leather upholstery and the type of base –– and observe the components being individually assembled on site.

properties.NAME: Vitra Design Museum Shop
properties.DESCRIPTION: The shop on the ground floor of the VitraHaus offers a diverse range of design objects, home accessories and publications –– from Vitra, the Vitra Design Museum and other design manufacturers. Many of the product designs are based on the museum’s collection or exhibition research, following the aim to make the major classics of design history accessible to the public.

properties.NAME: Interior Studio
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Interior Studio is located on the ground floor opposite the main entrance of the VitraHaus. The studio offers an inspiring working atmosphere where you can view fabrics and material samples or attend a consultation appointment. An experienced team will create a mood board that can assist you in furnishing a living room or even an entire house.

properties.NAME: Home Inspiration
properties.DESCRIPTION: The stories behind the objects – from paintings, sculpture and furniture to illustrated books, travel souvenirs and other collector’s items – form the heart of this interior. It is precisely curated, and the spaciously arranged furniture and objects create a captivating whole reminiscent of an art exhibition. Primarily featuring pastel shades, the strong individual colours and selected patterns stand out all the more.

properties.NAME: Loft
properties.DESCRIPTION: Sabine Marcelis opens up new perspectives on living with a bold installation in the VitraHaus Loft, using a cascading colour scheme. The Dutch designer also developed new colours and covers for two iconic Vitra products by Danish designer Verner Panton. These will be launched in a limited edition as installation spin-offs.  'The philosophy behind the design closely mirrors how we created our family home,' explains Marcelis who previously collaborated with the Vitra Design Museum in 2022 on 'Colour Rush!' – an exhibition at the Schaudepot where she organised iconic Vitra archive pieces by colour. 'It features a large open space divided into functional zones, delineated by colour. We then blended my creations with those of other designers, artists, and of course, Vitra furniture to create a cohesive whole.'

properties.NAME: VitraHaus
properties.DESCRIPTION: Originally intended as a showroom for the Vitra Home Collection, the VitraHaus has become a beacon for the Vitra brand over the past ten years –– both on campus and figuratively. Visible from afar, it marks the northern entrance to the Vitra Campus and signals unmistakably: Vitra not only produces furniture, but is also involved in architecture, art and home culture. In 2020, the VitraHaus is presenting a new interior concept on the occasion of its tenth anniversary.

properties.NAME: Dome
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Dome on the Vitra Campus was created in 1975 at Charter Industries and was the product of a collaboration with Thomas C. Howard. In 1978/79, it was used as a car showroom in Detroit (USA). In 2000, Rolf Fehlbaum bought it at an auction and installed it in Weil am Rhein in the same year. Today, the tent construction is used as a space for events and exhibitions.

properties.NAME: Factory Building
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Factory building, designed by Frank Gehry contains production rooms, a showroom, the test centre, the canteen and offices. The first floor windows look out onto the entire hall and allow visitors to observe the production stages in progress.

properties.NAME: Bus Stop
properties.DESCRIPTION: The glass walls of the bus stop made of polished steel provide views of the Vitra Campus and the wine-making village of Ötlingen. People waiting at the bus stops can sit on Wire Chairs, which were designed by Charles and Ray Eames and produced by Vitra. The two bus stops gracing the entrance to the Vitra Campus are unique and elegantly simple constructions designed by Jasper Morrison.

properties.NAME: Factory Building
properties.DESCRIPTION: The building, designed by the japanese architects SANAA is rounded in shape, but not quite circular, and is composed of two half-round concrete shells that are connected to one another. The oval form optimises logistical processes by allowing trucks sufficient room for circulating in.

properties.NAME: Factory Building
properties.DESCRIPTION: The second factory by Grimshaw from 1983 contains production facilities as well as the Citizen Office. This office environment was created by Sevil Peach in 2010. The founder of the London design studio Sevil Peach Gence Associates, SPGA, has worked with Vitra for over ten years and has designed office environments for and with Vitra as well as for leading international companies.

properties.NAME: Factory Building
properties.DESCRIPTION: The large and simple brick building designed by Álvaro Siza is reminiscent of anonymous factory buildings from the 19th century and is extremely unobtrusive in comparison to the other buildings on the grounds. The most eye-catching feature of the building is its curved bridge roof, which connects the building to the neighbouring one.

properties.NAME: Factory Building
properties.DESCRIPTION: In 1981, Nicholas Grimshaw's first construction on the Vitra Campus was seen as a homage to its own industrial usage and to Vitra’s technical expertise. Relying on prefabricated elements, planning to start-up of the production space was completed six months after the great fire as covered by insurance funds. Clad with horizontally striated façade elements made of corrugated aluminium sheeting, the building houses the production areas along with two showrooms.

properties.NAME: Vitra Campus Gallery
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Vitra Campus Gallery is the ideal starting point for exploring the Vitra Campus. Immerse yourself in its displays and find out about the history and architecture of this unique location. While the earliest buildings date from the 1950s, a major fire in 1981 opened the way for the Vitra Campus to be developed as a vibrant hub bringing together design, architecture, nature, and culinary delights. As the Vitra Campus continues to grow and evolve, the Vitra Campus Gallery also looks at recent projects continuing the site's unique architectural history. Explore and discover the Vitra Campus and be inspired by its richly creative environment. Your journey starts here.

properties.NAME: Vitra Design Museum
properties.DESCRIPTION: Since its opening in 1989, the Vitra Design Museum has become one of the world’s leading museums of design. It is dedicated to the research and presentation of design, past and present, and examines design’s relationship to architecture, art and everyday culture. The museum annually mounts two major temporary exhibitions in its main building designed by Frank Gehry. The neighbouring Vitra Design Museum Gallery showcases current positions in design and architecture.

properties.NAME: Conference Pavilion
properties.DESCRIPTION: The 1993 construction of the Conference Pavilion by Tadao Ando was the architect’s first building outside Japan. The calm and restrained structure encompasses an assortment of conference rooms. It is characterized by a highly ordered spatial articulation with a large part of its volume concealed below grade.

properties.NAME: Balancing Tools
properties.DESCRIPTION: On the seventieth birthday of Willi Fehlbaum, Vitra’s founder, his children presented him with the sculpture “Balancing Tools”. Erected on the grounds between the main road and the complex of buildings, it depicts the tools of the furniture maker juxtaposed with one another on an oversized scale. It was in Claes Oldenburg’s studio that Vitra Chairman Rolf Fehlbaum met Frank Gehry for the very first time.

properties.NAME: Oudolf Garten
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Oudolf Garten on the Vitra Campus in Weil am Rhein is an artfully composed wilderness. The balanced combination of plants - or ‘community’, as Piet Oudolf calls it - with its interwoven blend of flowers in many hues is reminiscent of an Impressionist painting. Around 30,000 plants with different strengths and weaknesses, blooming periods and life cycles fill an area of 4,000 square metres, creating a garden of ever-changing colours throughout the entire year.

properties.NAME: Fire Station
properties.DESCRIPTION: Designed by Zaha Hadid, the Fire Station on the Vitra Campus was the Iraqi- British architect’s first major built work. The jaggedly expressive volumes contrast with the orthogonal order of the adjacent factory buildings, like an explosion frozen in time. The sculpture-like structure was originally used to house a company fire brigade. Today it serves as a distinctive venue for events as well as installations by Vitra and exhibitions by the Vitra Design Museum.

properties.NAME: Vitra Slide Tower
properties.DESCRIPTION: The 30-metre-high Vitra Slide Tower by Carsten Höller is located along the Álvaro-Siza-Promenade, which connects the north and south parts of the Vitra Campus. Accessible to the public in good weather, the freestanding tower not only offers new perspectives of the Vitra Campus, but also invites visitors to experiencing a unique sliding adventure.

properties.NAME: Blockhaus
properties.DESCRIPTION: Blockhaus is a small building by the German artist Thomas Schütte. It provides shelter and a watering place for visitors to the Vitra Campus. Set on a slightly irregular hexagonal footprint, it is constructed from untreated Nordic pine.

properties.NAME: Vitra Schaudepot
properties.DESCRIPTION: The collection of the Vitra Design Museum ranks among the most important holdings of furniture design worldwide. It contains some 7000 pieces of furniture dating from 1800 to the present, a vast assemblage of lighting objects and numerous archives, as well as the estates of several prominent designers. Since 2016, approximately 400 key objects are on permanent display in the Vitra Schaudepot, which was designed by Basel-based architects Herzog & de Meuron.

properties.NAME: Ring & Ruisseau
properties.DESCRIPTION: Ring & Ruisseau were conceived by the French designers and artists Ronan and Erwan Bouroullec and have been part of the Vitra Campus since 2018. Ruisseau is a narrow channel carved in a marble base and filled with running water. Ring is a circular platform made of galvanised steel, which appears to float above the ground. Encircling a cherry tree, it serves as a collective bench.

properties.NAME: Bell, from: 24 Stops
properties.DESCRIPTION: Around five kilometres long, the Rehberger-Weg links two countries, two municipalities, two cultural institutions – and countless stories. The path runs between Weil am Rhein and Riehen, between the Fondation Beyeler and the Vitra Campus. Guided by ‘24 Stops’, 24 waymarkers created by the artist Tobias Rehberger, walkers can explore a uniquely diverse natural and cultural landscape.

properties.NAME: Airstream Kiosk
properties.DESCRIPTION: The original Airstream trailer, a 20’ 1968 Globetrotter, was discovered by a trucker scout in Nevada and shipped to Hamburg, Germany. During the summer months, it is used as a take-away restaurant and also increases the culinary offers available on the Vitra Campus.

properties.NAME: New Products
properties.DESCRIPTION: Exclusive presentation of new products, primarily from the Home Collection.

properties.NAME: Sofa & Home Office
properties.DESCRIPTION: Sofas take the centre stage in almost every living room. Their size, shape, materials and colours define the character of any interior setting. The actual purpose of a sofa never varies: it should provide exceptional comfort. Vitra sofas always fulfil this goal, however varied their appearance. Thanks to an extensive portfolio, Vitra has the right sofa for every interior style, need and preference.  The selection of Vitra lounge chairs spans from legendary classics to contemporary designs, from small to expansive models, from lightweight, unupholstered side chairs to soft recliners with comfort functions. This makes them as diverse as the people who use them.  The redesigned area features a number of curated scenes in which Vitra sofas and lounge chairs in a variety of colour palettes, evoke different atmospheres and interior styles – providing visitors with a wealth of inspiration for their home.  You can book your personal consultation with a furnishing expert via the Vitra Campus app, at sales.vitrahaus@vitra.comor by calling +49 7621 7023502.

properties.NAME: Vitra Schaudepot Shop
properties.DESCRIPTION: In the foyer of the Vitra Schaudepot, the shop presents a carefully selected assortment of design products, many are related to the chairs in the Schaudepot and the collection of design objects of the Vitra Design Museum, as also a large variety of publications and magazines on design and architecture.

properties.NAME: Depot Deli
properties.DESCRIPTION: The Depot Deli serves a varying selection of internationally inspired dishes. The take-away offerings are also suited for a quick snack on the go. In addition, the Depot Deli hosts the Depot Deli Breakfast Club every and a brunch with regional products.

properties.NAME: Vitra Designweg
properties.DESCRIPTION: On small revolving podiums, the 12 lantern-like showcases present miniatures of highlights of modern furniture design from the collection of the Vitra Design Museum. The route runs from the tram stop on line 8 in Weil am Rhein (20 minutes from Basel) along the footpath on Basler Strasse and Müllheimer Strasse to the south entrance of the Vitra Campus.

properties.NAME: Designer Village
properties.DESCRIPTION: Along the walls, eight small display windows showcase products by the most important designers with whom Vitra collaborates.

properties.NAME: Marketplace & Consultation point
properties.DESCRIPTION: What products are featured here? Vitra accessories and third-party products from the Home Inspiration scenes. Our consultation team will be happy to answer your questions.

properties.NAME: Torre Numero Due
properties.DESCRIPTION: Measuring almost three metres high, the sculpture is a blend of art, architecture and design. The object by artist and designer Nathalie Du Pasquier is located on the Álvaro Siza Promenade in front of one of the concrete walls of the Fire Station by Zaha Hadid.

properties.NAME: Diogene
properties.DESCRIPTION: Renzo Piano and his architecture office Renzo Piano Building Workshop have developed a living unit which unites all elementary functions of temporary living under one roof in a modest living space of six square metres. As the modern interpretation of an archaic cabin, “Diogene” is the smallest building of the architectural ensemble in Weil am Rhein.

properties.NAME: Petrol Station
properties.DESCRIPTION: The petrol station designed in 1953 by Jean Prouvé and his brother Henry is one of the first serially manufactured petrol stations. It was built about 1953 for Mobiloil Socony-Vacuum and stood at “Relais des Sangliers” in the Département Haute-Loire. Created modularly of individual pieces, this one of only three remaining stations was installed on the Vitra Campus in 2003.

properties.NAME: Designer Library
properties.DESCRIPTION: This small library is devoted to the designers and architects who have created products and structures for Vitra. You are welcome to take a seat and browse through the various publications.

properties.NAME: Home Inspirations
properties.DESCRIPTION: Giving expression to feelings and moods and embodying them in the ambiance of the room is the essence of each object in this interior. Obsessive, avant-garde and eccentric furnishings and accessories together form an iconic and sophisticated ensemble in red and pink tones, with almost experimentallooking breaks in colour.

properties.NAME: Home Inspirations
properties.DESCRIPTION: Harmonious colours and exquisite, carefully coordinated materials of the highest quality generate an impression of understated timeless elegance in this interior.

properties.NAME: Home Inspirations
properties.DESCRIPTION: Simplicity, warmth, natural surfaces and light hues come together in an environment further enhanced by the charm of nostalgic references. Enduring materials that age with a beautiful patina give the space a calm, understated atmosphere, encouraging spontaneity and facilitating flexible use.

properties.NAME: Chairs & Tables
properties.DESCRIPTION: White industrial racks with a light, modern appearance characterise this floor. They showcase the entire range of Vitra chairs in three rows, with a dedicated area for the Artek brand. Dining tables in a range of shapes, sizes and colours are also on display. For advice and information on the products you are interested in, our team is at your disposal.

properties.NAME: Khudi Bari
properties.DESCRIPTION: In Bangladesh, floods are becoming more frequent as a result of climate change, forcing countless numbers of people to look for a new home. Against this backdrop, Bangladeshi architect Marina Tabassum and her team have developed the Khudi Bari, or small house: a low-cost structure that can be erected, dismantled, transported and reassembled elsewhere by the residents themselves. A Khudi Bari was constructed on the Vitra Campus in Weil am Rhein as an example of a certain architectural mindset and a concrete response to problems exacerbated by the climate crisis.  Khudi Bari literally means ‘small house’. It is an extremely low-cost, lightweight structure that can be assembled and dismantled by hand – without electricity or any other means of mechanical power. Marina Tabassum’s team has been building these houses in the chars together with relief organisations and community groups, improving existential conditions for a vulnerable population living at the absolute minimum subsistence level. Over one hundred Khudi Bari have already been installed and more are yet to come.  What is a Khudi Bari doing on the banks of the Rhine? The Vitra Campus in Weil am Rhein is an active industrial site that has embraced a programme of architectural experimentation and cultural engagement and welcomes hundreds of thousands of visitors every year. Together with the recent planting of a Miyawaki forest on the grounds and the construction of the Garden House by Tsuyoshi Tane, the Khudi Bari is an expression of a new orientation on the Vitra Campus. Climate change demands innovative solutions. What endures is the commitment to good design: Khudi Bari demonstrates that architecture of necessity can also be aesthetically appealing.

properties.NAME: Circle Store
properties.DESCRIPTION: Mit den Circle Stores ermöglichen wir den Produkten ein zweites Leben und setzen damit nachhaltiges Wirtschaften in die Praxis um. Ab Mitte Oktober 2023 gibt es neu auch auf dem Vitra Campus in Weil am Rhein einen Circle Store. Weitere Circle Store gibt es in Brüssel und Amsterdam.
